properties.Name: StoreProductRetailMerchandisingCondition
properties.Description: The retail merchandising condition(s) associated with the store product  during the period.

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: RetailMerchandisingConditionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a retail merchandising condition type.

Columns.Name: StoreProductLiftPercentage
Columns.Description: The % increase in sales (in $ or volume) obtained due to retailer merchandising.  Calculated as (Incremental/Base) * 100 = Lift %.

Columns.Name: StoreProductLiftAmount
Columns.Description: The amount increase in sales (in $ or volume) obtained due to retailer merchandising.

Columns.Name: StoreProductPromotedSalesQuantity
Columns.Description:
The quantity of product sold in stores which had some type of merchandising at any point during the week.  

1) see how highly promoted a category/segment/brand is and 

2) to quantify trade costs or calculate merchandising efficiency.

Columns.Name: StoreProductPromotedSalesAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount of product sold in stores which had some type of merchandising at any point during the week.  

1) see how highly promoted a category/segment/brand is and 

2) to quantify trade costs or calculate merchandising efficiency.

Columns.Name: StoreDisplayExecutionPercentage
Columns.Description:
Measures how much display activity took place during weeks when there was also a feature.  

You want as much display as possible to happen when features are also happening, as the impact of the 2 tactics together is always higher than when display happens alone, assuming the same price point.

Calculated as (weeks of Any Display)/(weeks of Feature & Display).  

Typically display Execution ranges between 0-100% and higher is better.

Columns.Name: MerchandisingEfficiencyPercentage
Columns.Description:
This measures the effectiveness of your merchandising.  

This measure tells you the % of promoted volume that you would not have sold if there was no promotion.  

Calculated as incremental volume/promoted volume.  Higher is better.   

For example, if your efficiency is 10%, this means 90% of the volume you sold during the promotion would have been sold anyway, even without the merchandising.-100% and higher is better.

Columns.Name: StoreProductRetailMerchandisingConditionNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the store product retail merchandising condition.
